headline: Barnes rakes in almost $150K after Johnson enters Wisconsin Senate race
author: Mychael Schnell
sentences: Mandela Barnes (D) has raked in almost $150,000 in the days since Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) announced that he will run for reelection in the Badger State, giving the Democratic candidate a fundraising boost in a 12-person primary battle.

He said that while he would prefer to retire, he decided to run again to fight against Democrats' control in Washington and disastrous policies.?
The Cook Political Report says the race for Johnson's Senate seat is a toss-up.
An internal poll released by the campaign on Friday found that he has a 29-point lead over Milwaukee Bucks executive Alex Lasry and is 30 points ahead of Wisconsin Treasurer Sarah Godlewski.
Barnes's campaign said more than 5,000 individual donors have contributed since Sunday morning, when Johnson announced he will run for a third term representing Wisconsin in the U.S. Senate.
The roughly three-day haul gives the Barnes campaign strong footing in the Democratic primary race, where 12 candidates are running for the party's nomination to take on Johnson.
Johnson said Sunday that he will run for reelection in the Badger State, breaking a vow he made in 2016 to seek only two six-year terms in the upper chamber.
A number of top Democrats have already thrown their support behind the lieutenant governor, including House Majority Whip James Clyburn (S.C.) and Sens.
Barnes released his first policy plan last month, which included passing new voting rights legislation and a call for the filibuster to be abolished.
Twenty-nine percent of respondents, however, said they are still undecided on who to support in the race.
Barnes has emerged as an early front-runner in the field.
